item.title: Day 139, 2 Samuel 19-21
item.description: When the army heard that David was grieving because of his son, the day of victory became a day or mourning.

item.title: Day 138, Psalm 26, 40, 58, 61, 62, 64
item.description: In psalm 26, David contrasts himself with the wicked. Unlike the wicked, he has kept the law of God and walked with integrity.

item.title: Day 137, 2 Samuel 16-18
item.description: Ziba meets David while David is fleeing. He tells David that Mephibosheth was also vying for the throne. As a result, David gives to Ziba the possessions of Mephibosheth.

item.title: Day 136, Psalm 3-4, 12-13, 28, 55
item.description: As David flees from his son Absalom, he prays to God to save him. He trusts in God to sustain him and to answer his prayer.

item.title: Day 135, 2 Samuel 13-15
item.description: After the events with Bathsheba, David’s house falls into turmoil and strife. David’s son Amnon loved his sister Tamar. On the advice of Jonadab, David’s nephew, he lured Tamar into his room on the pretense of being sick and raped her.

item.title: Day 134, Psalm 32, 51, 86, 122
item.description: Psalm 32 speaks of the those who have been forgiven by God. To be forgiven by God means that their sin has been covered up by God; however, to do this, they must uncover their sin before God.

item.title: Day 133, 2 Samuel 11-12, 1 Chronicles 20
item.description: At this time, Israel went to war against the Ammonites. However, David stayed in Jerusalem. While David was in Jerusalem, he saw Bathsheba, who was purifying herself from uncleanness.

item.title: Day 132, Psalm 65-67, 69-70
item.description: Psalms 65-67 share the common theme of praising God for his goodness and salvation. The strength of God is often depicted using the forces of nature, while the holiness and justice of God are expressed with either praise of God’s salvation or an appeal to God to execute judgement on the wicked.

item.title: Day 131, 2 Samuel 10, 1 Chronicles 19, Psalm 20
item.description: Nahash, king of the Ammonites died. David sent men to comfort his son Hanun as a gesture of friendship twowards the late king.

item.title: Day 130, Psalm 50, 53, 60, 75
item.description: Psalm 50 expresses how God looks at the heart. God puts into perspective how the simple acts of sacrifice without having a heart after God mean nothing.

item.title: Day 129, 2 Samuel 8-9, 1 Chronicles 18
item.description: God gave David victory over his enemies wherever he went. He defeated the Philistines, Moab, Edom, Syria, and more. The fame of David spread far, and because of these victories, other nations brought gifts to David.

item.title: Day 128, Psalm 25, 29, 33, 36, 39
item.description: In psalm 25, David asks God to teach him his ways. David is fully aware of how he is, thus his request cannot be made without acknowledging his own sin.

item.title: Day 127, 2 Samuel 6-7, 1 Chronicles 17
item.description: David brings the ark to Jerusalem, but becomes afraid of God when God kills Uzzah for touching the ark. He sends it to the house of Obed-edom, where the ark stayed for some time.

item.title: Day 126, Psalm 89, 96, 100-101, 132
item.description: Psalm 89 sings of the steadfast love of God. The primary way which it expresses this is through the covenant between David and God.

item.title: Day 125, Psalm 1-2, 15, 22-24, 47, 68
item.description: Psalm 1 contrasts one who takes delight in the law of God and one who does not. Those who delight in the law of God are blessed and will prosper, whereas the wicked will be judged and be driven away.

item.title: Day 124, 1 Chronicles 13-16
item.description: David sought to bring the ark of God into Jerusalem, since Saul did not seek God while he was king. As the ark was being brought in, there was much celebration.

item.title: Day 123, Psalm 106-107
item.description: Psalm 106 is about the goodness of God. At first glance, it seems that this is simply a psalm of thanksgiving.

item.title: Day 122, Psalm 133
item.description: Psalm 133 expresses how good it is when there is unity among brothers. It compares it to the anointing oil running down the beard of Aaron the priest and the blessing of rain that falls on the city of Zion.

item.title: Day 121, 2 Samuel 5, 1 Chronicles 11-12
item.description: At this point in time, Israel approached David in Hebron and requested him to be king. David made a covenant with the people of Israel - his kingship was a covenantal relationship between himself and Israel.

item.title: Day 120, Psalm 102-104
item.description: Psalm 102 expresses the heart of someone afflicted and experiencing suffering. It is during these times when the author feels like God is punishing him for something.

item.title: Day 119, 1 Chronicles 7-10
item.description: The author recounts the genealogies of the tribes of Issachar, Benjamin, Naphtali, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Asher. Each genealogy is of varying lengths with varying degrees of detail, likely reflecting the sources that were accessible to the author.

item.title: Day 118, Psalm 81, 88, 92-93
item.description: Psalm 81 appears to switch between the perspective of the author and the perspective of God. Yet, it is apparent that the heart of both desires that God’s people listen and obey God.

item.title: Day 117, 1 Chronicles 6
item.description: The author recounts the genealogy of Levi. Of the sons of Kohath came Aaron, Moses, and Ahitub. The line of Kohath was recorded until the exile by Babylon.

item.title: Day 115, 1 Chronicles 3-5
item.description: Chapter 3 through 5 follow the genealogies of the tribes of Judah, Simeon, Reuban, Gad, and Manasseh. Chapter 3 also recounts the genealogy of David.

item.title: Day 116, Psalm 73, 77-78
item.description: Psalm 73 seeks to explore and understand why the wicked prosper while the righteous suffer. It conveys the feelings of the heart when it says that it is envious of the prosperity of the wicked.

item.title: Day 114, Psalm 43-45, 49, 84-85, 87
item.description: Psalm 43 appeals to God to lift up the author and to defend him against the wicked. He questions why he is oppressed even though he is faithful.

item.title: Day 113, 1 Chronicles 1-2
item.description: 1 Chronicles opens up with a genealogy from Adam to David. This makes sense as the book of Chronicles was written while Israel was in exile.

item.title: Day 112, Psalm 6, 8-10, 14, 16, 19, 21
item.description: Psalm 6 is a cry for help to God during suffering and a statement of hope in the steadfast love of God.

item.title: Day 111, 2 Samuel 1-4
item.description: The news of Saul’s death reached David by an Amalekite. The Amalekite lied about how Saul died, potentially trying to earn favour with David.

item.title: Day 110, Psalm 121, 123-125, 128-130
item.description: These psalms are a collection of short prayers proclaiming the steadfastness of God. Similar themes run through each of them, including steadfastness, justice, and protection from evil.

item.title: Day 109, 1 Samuel 28-31
item.description: Israel and the Philistines go to war. Saul tries to inquire of God, but receives silence. He makes the decision to ask a medium to summon Samuel from the dead.

item.title: Day 108, Psalm 17, 35, 54, 63
item.description: In psalm 17, David pleas his righteousness before God. He compares himself to the wicked who speak and act against God.

item.title: Day 107, 1 Samuel 25-27
item.description: Samuel dies. David comes across Nabal, a Calebite. After spending some time guarding Nabal’s flock to gain trust, he sends men to request for some food as it was a feast day.

item.title: Day 106, Psalm 56, 120, 140-142
item.description: Psalm 56 is an appeal from David to God to be gracious to him. He proclaims his trust and assurance in God protection.

item.title: Day 105, Psalms 7, 27, 31, 34, 52
item.description: These psalms speak of God’s deliverance of David from his enemies. Psalm 7 is a prayer requesting God to rise up on his behalf.

item.title: Day 104, 1 Samuel 21-24
item.description: David flees to Nob, where he requests bread for the priests. The only bread present was the bread of the Presence - only the priests were permitted to eat it.

item.title: Day 103, 1 Samuel 18-20, Psalm 11, 59
item.description: After David’s victory over Goliath, Jonathan and David became best friends. They loved each other very much. But Saul became jealous of David, and tried to kill him twice.

item.title: Day 102, 1 Samuel 15-17
item.description: God gives Saul the command to completely destroy the Amalekites for how they treated Israel when Israel came out of Egypt.

item.title: Day 101, 1 Samuel 13-14
item.description: Saul goes to war against the Philistines. However, increasing defections begin to make Saul very nervous. As a result, instead of waiting for Samuel to come, he offers the sacrifice unlawfully.

item.title: Day 100, 1 Samuel 9-12
item.description: Saul is introduced as a Benjaminite searching for the missing donkeys of his father. Unable to find them, he turns to the seer, who is Samuel.

item.title: Day 99, 1 Samuel 4-8
item.description: Israel went to war against the Philistines and were defeated in battle. In response, Israel brought the the ark of the covenant into their camp.

item.title: Day 98, 1 Samuel 1-3
item.description: The birth of Samuel gives a glimpse into the hearts of the people of Israel and the priesthood of God. Hannah was barren, yet persistently prayed to God for a child.

item.title: Day 97, Ruth
item.description: The story of Ruth shows how God is moving everything and everyone to where he wants them to be. Although Ruth had lost her husband, and Naomi had lost her family, land, and people, God took them from where they were in Moab and moved them back into Israel at a time when the harvest was good.

item.title: Day 96, Judges 19-21
item.description: The final narrative in Judges begins the same way as the previous, emphasizing that there was no king in Israel back then.

item.title: Day 95, Judges 16-18
item.description: The story of Samson continues with Samson falling for a prostitute and almost getting ambushed. Afterwards, he falls for Delilah. The Philistine lords tasked her with finding out Samson’s weakness.

item.title: Day 94, Judges 13-15
item.description: The birth of Samson was heralded by the angel of the LORD, who appeared first to Manoah’s wife and then to both of them at Manoah’s request.

item.title: Day 93, Judges 10-12
item.description: Tola and Jair served as judges for Israel for a number years. After they died, Israel disobeyed God again, so they were given into the hands of the Philistines and Ammonites.

item.title: Day 92, Judges 8-9
item.description: Gideon and his men pursued Oreb and Zeeb, the kings of Midian. They became exhausted on the way, and asked for food at the cities of Succoth and Penuel.

item.title: Day 90, Joshua 3-5
item.description: God left several nations behind to test Israel, to see if they would keep his commandments. Unfortunately, as God said would happen, the people of Israel and the other nations intermixed, and the Canaanites became a snare for Israel.

item.title: Day 91, Judges 6-7
item.description: Again, Israel did what was evil before God, so God let Midian rule over them. The oppression of Israel was very harsh, and Israel cried out to God.

item.title: Day 89, Judges 1-2
item.description: After Joshua died, Israel continued their conquest of Canaan. However, there eventually came a time when Israel stopped driving out the Canaanites.

item.title: Day 88, Joshua 22-24
item.description: With the land subdued and portioned, Joshua sends the eastern tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh back home beyond the Jordan.

item.title: Day 87, Joshua 19-21
item.description: The inheritance for Simeon, Zebulun, Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Dan were given in that order. Of note is the territory of Simeon, as it is within the territory of Judah.

item.title: Day 86, Joshua 16-18
item.description: Joshua continues to allot the land to the people of Israel. Following the allotment of Judah, the tribes Ephraim and Manasseh received their portion.

item.title: Day 85, Joshua 12-15
item.description: Moses defeated the kings east of the Jordan. The land there was given to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.

item.title: Day 84, oshua 9-11
item.description: The kings in the land heard of what happened at Ai, and five of them gathered to fight against Israel. However, the Gibeonites deceived Israel into sparing them, showing the dangers of relying on oneself instead of God.

item.title: Day 83, Joshua 5-8
item.description: The people west of the Jordan heard of Israel’s Jordan crossing by God’s hand, and they all lost heart. Remarkably, this was the time when God told Joshua to circumcise the new generation of Israel, since they would be putting themselves in a very vulnerable state in the middle of enemy territory.

item.title: Day 82, Joshua 1-4
item.description: Joshua officially takes over leadership of Israel. God reiterates what he said before to Joshua, but this time in his new capacity as leader.

item.title: Day 81, Deuteronomy 32-34, Psalm 91
item.description: Moses gives Israel a song and a blessing. In the song, it speaks of the righteousness and faithfulness of God. It also speaks of the greatness and sovereignty of God.

item.title: Day 80, Deuteronomy 30-31
item.description: Moses tells Israel that after the blessing and the curse have come to pass, then Israel will remember God, and God will bring them back from exile.

item.title: Day 79, Deuteronomy 28-29
item.description: God tells Israel the blessings they can expect when they faithfully obey him. These include blessings for their work as well as blessings for their wombs.

item.title: Day 77, Deuteronomy 21-23
item.description: Many of the laws given here have recurring themes. Their punishments are harsh so that whatever evil that had been committed in Israel can be purged.

item.title: Day 78, Deuteronomy 24-27
item.description: Laws for divorce are given to Israel, in addition to various other laws. Some laws include reminders of past experiences that Israel had with whatever the law is addressing.

item.title: Day 76, Deuteronomy 17-20
item.description: The laws that Moses recounts for Israel heavily emphasize judgement and grace. Many of these laws show how seriously God takes sin, as many of these offences are punishable by death or exile.

item.title: Day 75, Deuteronomy 14-16
item.description: Moses tells the Israelites about the laws regarding clean and unclean food again. He reminds them that they are to live in the way God commands them because they are a holy people to God, and God has chosen them as a treasured possession.

item.title: Day 74, Deuteronomy 11-13
item.description: Moses charges Israel to love God and keep the entire commandment. He goes over the blessings that God has in store for them, but also sets a curse before them should they turn away from God and worship other gods.

item.title: Day 73, Deuteronomy 8-10
item.description: Moses reminds the people to remember God. Just as how Israel witnessed God providing for them and dwelling among them in the wilderness, they are to remember God and keep his commandments when they have settled and have received the blessings of God.

item.title: Day 72, Deuteronomy 5-7
item.description: Moses presents the covenant God made with the people of Israel at Horeb (Sinai). He emphasizes the setting which the covenant was made in and the people’s reaction to it.

item.title: Day 71
item.description: God gave King Og of Bashan over to the Israelites. Thus, Israel took control of the territory of two of the Amorite kings.

item.title: Day 70, Deuteronomy 1-2
item.description: Moses recounts the Journey of Israel after leaving Mount Sinai. When they arrived at the edge of Canaan, God commanded them to go forth and take for themselves the inheritance that he promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

item.title: Day 69, Numbers 35-36
item.description: A total of forty-eight cities and the surrounding pasturelands are to be given to the Levites to live in. Of those, six of them are cities of refuge.

item.title: Day 68, Numbers 33-34
item.description: Chapter 33 recounts the journey of Israel by dividing it into segments. The Israelites left Egypt triumphantly in the sight of the Egyptians.

item.title: Day 67, Numbers 31-32
item.description: God orders Israel to take vengeance on Midian, for they caused Israel to sin at Peor. Balaam and the kings of Midian were killed.

item.title: Day 66, Numbers 28-30
item.description: God details laws concerning offerings at different times of the day and throughout the year. Each offering often includes some sort of animal, grain offering, drink offering, food offering, or sin offering.

item.title: Day 65, Numbers 26-27
item.description: God orders Moses to take a second census. Despite all the disasters God brought on Israel for their disobedience, remarkably, their total numbers were largely the same as the time of the first census.

item.title: Day 64, Numbers 23-25
item.description: Balaam gave a total of four oracles concerning Israel. Balaam went to look for omens from God for the first two, while for the final two, he was aware that God intended to bless Israel and did not go to look for omens from God.

item.title: Day 63, Numbers 21-22
item.description: The king of Arad is destroyed and his cities devoted to destruction. Afterwards, the people became impatient at their journey and grumbled against God and Moses.

item.title: Day 62, Numbers 18-20
item.description: God tells Aaron his duties and those of the Levites. The Levites are to keep guard and service the tent of meeting.

item.title: Day 61, Numbers 16-17
item.description: Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and 250 other chiefs of Israel rebel against Moses and Aaron. Korah was among those who guarded and serviced the holy things.

item.title: Day 60, Numbers 14-15, Psalm 90
item.description: On hearing the report of the spies, the people rebel and wish to return to Egypt. Moses, Aaron, Joshua, and Caleb were greatly grieved, for they believed that God would deliver the inhabitants of Canaan into their land.

item.title: Day 59, Numbers 11-13
item.description: After forming the covenant and leaving Sinai, the people begin complaining about their misfortunes. Fire comes down and consumes parts of the camp, and Moses prays on behalf of the people for the fire to stop.

item.title: Day 58, Numbers 8-10
item.description: God orders Moses to cleanse the Levites by sprinkling the water of purification and giving a grain and sin offering. The Levites are offered as a wave offering to God before the entire congregation.

item.title: Day 57, Numbers 7
item.description: Once the tabernacle and everything in it was consecrated, the chiefs of each tribe of Israel brought their offerings. The wagons and oxen were distributed to the sons of Gershon and Merari.

item.title: Day 56, Numbers 5-6
item.description: A person who is unclean is to be put outside the camp because God, who is holy, dwells within the camp.

item.title: Day 55, Numbers 3-4
item.description: A count of the sons of Aaron and the Levites is performed. At the same time, the duties of the Levites are given.

item.title: Day 54, Numbers 1-2
item.description: God tells Moses to take a census of Israel. All those who are of fighting age are to be counted. The smallest tribe is Manasseh and the largest is Judah.

item.title: Day 53, Leviticus 26-27
item.description: God tells Israel the blessings he will give them if they obey him. If Israel obeys God, they will have plentiful harvests and peace, overwhelming victory over their enemies, and their land will be free from wild beasts.

item.title: Day 52, Leviticus 24-25
item.description: Commands regarding the arrangements for the lamp and bread of the tabernacle are given. The punishment for blasphemy is death, though this law is different in that it calls for the entire congregation of Israel to stone the blasphemer.

item.title: Day 51, Leviticus 22-23
item.description: God gives instructions regarding what is to happen should Aaron or his sons become unclean. If that is to happen, that person is cut off from God for a day.

item.title: Day 50, Leviticus 19-21
item.description: God begins the next section of laws by declaring his holiness and how he is the God of Israel. Because he is holy, the people are also to be holy in the way they live.

item.title: Day 49, Leviticus 16-18
item.description: God gives laws for the Day of Atonement, a day which Aaron is to make atonement for the entirety of Israel.

item.title: Day 48, Leviticus 14-15
item.description: God gives laws regarding bodily discharges and the cleansing of lepers and houses. Throughout the entire passage, God makes it very clear that there is a tight relationship between one’s physical state and spiritual state.

item.title: Day 47, Leviticus 11-13
item.description: God gives instructions regarding what the Israelites can and cannot eat. Among the clean animals are those with a split hoof, cloven-footed, and chew the cud.

item.title: Day 46, Leviticus 8-10
item.description: Aaron and his sons are consecrated as priests according to the previous instructions given by God in Exodus. They are washed and clothed with the priest’s garments.

item.title: Day 45, Leviticus 5-7
item.description: God also takes into account one’s ability to give the sin offering when he gives the laws. Among the offences that require a sin offering include uncleanness, failure to testify, or any sort of rash oath.

item.title: Day 44, Leviticus 1-4
item.description: The laws concerning burnt offerings, peace offerings, and sin offerings all use some sort of animal as the offering. All sacrifices and offerings take place just outside the tent of meeting.

item.title: Day 43, Exodus 39-40
item.description: The Israelites made the priestly garments as God commanded Moses. They made the ephod, the engraved onyx stones, the breastpiece with its four rows of jewels, the blue robe of the ephod, the bells and pomegranates, coats, turban, sash, and the inscribed plate of the crown.

item.title: Day 42, Exodus 36-38
item.description: The Israelites give their contributions for the tabernacle out of their own free will. They gave so much that they had more than needed.

item.title: Day 41, Exodus 33-35
item.description: Moses and the people are ordered to head to the Promised land. However, God will no longer go among the Israelites even though he will still drive out the people there.

item.title: Day 40, Exodus 30-32
item.description: Laws for the altar of incense are given. Only Aaron is able to burn incense on it. No unauthorized incense or offerings are allowed on the altar.

item.title: Day 39, Exodus 28-29
item.description: Instructions for the priests' garments are given. These garments are to be worn by Aaron and his sons. Aaron’s garments are to be made of gold, linen, and various yarns.

item.title: Day 38, Exodus 25-27
item.description: God gives instructions for the sanctuary so that he can dwell among the people. The materials to be collected are to be given by those whose hearts have been moved.

item.title: Day 37. Exodus 22-24
item.description: Laws regarding repayment of damages are given. These laws show that God ensures that those who are wronged are repaid, and those who do wrong pay the full amount.

item.title: Day 36, Exodus 19-21
item.description: The Israelites arrive at Mount Sinai. There, God begins to establish the Mosaic covenant. As the offspring of Abraham, Israel inherits the Abrahamic covenant as a people and get a new covenant, one that would set apart Israel as God’s treasured possession.

item.title: Day 35, Exodus 16-18
item.description: As Israel travelled, they complained against Moses and Aaron, for they did not have any food. Moses brought their complaint to God, and God promised to send food.

item.title: Day 34, Exodus 13-15
item.description: The Feast of Unleavened bread was established so that the people of Israel may remember their deliverance from their Egyptian oppressors, for they left in haste.

item.title: Day 33, Exodus 10-12
item.description: During the plague of locusts, Pharaoh’s servants urge Pharaoh to let the people of Israel go. At this point, the economy of Egypt was ruined.

item.title: Day 32, Exodus 7-9
item.description: In effect, Moses is God’s ambassador, as his words are the words of God. God reveals to Moses what is about to happen to Egypt, and charges them to go to Pharaoh again.

item.title: Day 31, Exodus 4-6
item.description: Moses continues to voice his fears and complaints. God addresses his first by giving him three signs to perform so that Israel may believe.

item.title: Day 30, Exodus 1-3
item.description: The children of Israel increased in number and strength. In time, the Egyptians began to fear the Israelites and oppressed them, making them slaves.

item.title: Day 29, Genesis 48-50
item.description: The progression of the final story is different, as one would expect for God to appear to the next inheritor of the Abrahamic covenant.

item.title: Day 28, Genesis 46-47
item.description: Jacob and his family begins the journey to Egypt. God promises that he will go down with them to Egypt, and by his hand, he will bring Jacob back up.

item.title: Day 27, Genesis 43-45
item.description: The food that the brothers got from Egypt has now run out, and Jacob tells them to go back to Egypt to get more food.

item.title: Day 26, Genesis 41-42
item.description: During Joseph’s imprisonment, Pharaoh had two dreams. However, no one in Egypt was able to tell Pharaoh what it meant. It was at this time that the cup bearer remembered how Joseph interpreted their dreams for them and told Pharaoh about Joseph.

item.title: Day 25, Genesis 38-40
item.description: Judah became the father of three sons. The first son married Tamar, but he died shortly after without a heir. His second son was to raise offspring with Tamar on behalf of the first, but he didn’t want to have his brother’s offspring.

item.title: Day 24, Genesis 35-37
item.description: God has now fulfilled his end of the deal with Jacob. He has safely brought Jacob back to the land of Canaan and protected him from his brother and given him prosperity.

item.title: Day 23, Genesis 32-34
item.description: Throughout this passage, we see further evidence of God using events and people to separate for himself a nation distinct that will inherit the Abrahamic covenant.

item.title: Day 22, Genesis 30-31
item.description: From Bilhah on behalf of Rachel, Dan and Naphtali were born. From Zilpah on behalf of Lea, Gad and Asher were born.

item.title: Day 21, Genesis 27-29
item.description: As the firstborn, Esau is called in to Isaac so that he may eat of the game Esau hunts and bless him.

item.title: Day 20, Genesis 25-26
item.description: Abraham had many other sons after Isaac, but the inheritance went only to Isaac. Before Jacob and Esau are born to Isaac, God tells Isaac and Rebekah that the two children are two nations, but the older will serve the younger.

item.title: Day 19, Genesis 22-24
item.description: When God tests Abraham, Abraham readily obeys, willing to give up the manifestation of God’s promise in obedience to God. Curiously, Abraham tells his son Isaac that God will provide the lamb, although God has not said anything regarding that.

item.title: Day 18, Genesis 19-21
item.description: When the two angels arrive at Sodom, Lot greets and invites them to spend the night at his house. However, the men of the city, in their wickedness, ask the two men for sex.

item.title: Day 17, Genesis 16-18
item.description: Sarai, unable to bear children, gives her servant Hagar to Abram. Abram consents, even though the covenant with God was made shortly prior to this.

item.title: Day 16, Genesis 12-15
item.description: God tells Abram to leave the land he is living in and go to a land that God will show him.

item.title: Day 15, Job 40-42
item.description: In the face of God’s majesty and revelation, Job finds no answer to God. God continues in his challenge to Job.

item.title: Day 14, Job 38-39
item.description: God responds to Job’s complaints in a speech placing emphasis on his sovereignty and power. Although Job may not remember or perceive his presence, God is there, moving the things in the world in accordance to his will.

item.title: Day 13, Job 35-37
item.description: Elihu opens his condemnation of Job much differently than his friends. Whereas the others launched accusations, Elihu acknowledges the suffering that Job is going through.

item.title: Day 12, Job 32-34
item.description: Elihu finally decides to speak up. He is angry at Job’s friends for failing to find an answer to Job and is angry at Job for justifying himself rather than God.

item.title: Day 11, Job 29-31
item.description: Job summarizes his defence in three sections. Job wishes for the old days when God blessed him. He was respected by others and honour was shown to him.

item.title: Day 10, Job 24-28
item.description: Job describes the suffering of the poor. Although they do much work, their work is in vain. There are cries and pleas for help, but there is no charge from God.

item.title: Day 9, Job 21-23
item.description: While Job’s friends continue to insist that the wicked are brought to ruin, Job counters by describing the prosperity of the wicked.

item.title: Day 8, Job 17-20
item.description: Job continues elaborating that apart from God, there is no hope. Although upright people see his suffering, none have lifted a finger to help him.

item.title: Day 7, Job 14-16
item.description: Job proceeds to talk about the pointlessness of life, since all men will eventually die. If that is so, then it makes sense for Job to want to bring his case before God.

item.title: Day 6, Job 10-13
item.description: Job continues with a plea to God, asking why God had brought so much suffering into his life. Zopher mocks Job in response, saying that Job is already getting repaid much less than his guilt deserves.

item.title: Day 5, Job 6-9
item.description: Job responds to Eliphaz’s answer. He maintains that his complaints are just and acknowledges once again the sovereignty of God. He maintains that he is still in obedience to God, as he finds the misfortunes that have come upon him to be in God’s will.

item.title: Day 4, Job 1-5
item.description: Job was one of the greatest men in the east. He was blameless and righteous before before God and feared God.

item.title: Day 3, Genesis 8-11
item.description: God remembered Noah and those that he had spared from the flood. Therefore, God caused the floodwaters to recede. When land could be seen, Noah sent out a raven and a dove several times, continually checking for the day which the floodwaters completely recede.

item.title: Day 2, Genesis 4-7
item.description: Adam and Eve had two sons, Cain and Abel. Both of them brought an offering to God, but God was only pleased with Abel’s offering of his flock’s firstborn and fat portions.

item.title: Day 1, Genesis 1-3
item.description: The world before creation is described as formless, empty, and dark. Yet, the presence of God is there, it is clear that wherever God is, something is bound to happen.
